text: <extra_id_0> Bik <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a novel death - inducing protein shares a distinct sequence motif with Bcl-2 family proteins and interacts with viral and cellular survival - promoting proteins .
The survival - promoting activity of the Bcl-2 family of proteins appears to be modulated by interactions between various cellular proteins .

We have identified a novel cellular protein , <extra_id_0> Bik <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , that interacts with the cellular survival - promoting proteins , <extra_id_0> Bcl-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Bcl-xL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , as well as the viral survival - promoting proteins , Epstein Barr virus - <extra_id_0> BHRF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and adenovirus <extra_id_0> E1B-19 kDa <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In transient transfection assays , <extra_id_0> Bik <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promotes cell death in a manner similar to the death - promoting members of the Bcl-2 family , <extra_id_0> Bax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Bak <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

This death - promoting activity of <extra_id_0> Bik <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can be suppressed by coexpression of <extra_id_0> Bcl-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Bcl-XL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> EBV-BHRF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and E1B-19 kDa proteins suggesting that <extra_id_0> Bik <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be a common target for both cellular and viral anti-apoptotic proteins .

While <extra_id_0> Bik <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> does not show overt homology to the <extra_id_0> BH1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> BH2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> conserved domains characteristic of the Bcl-2 family , it does share a 9 amino acid domain ( <extra_id_0> BH3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) with <extra_id_0> Bax <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Bak <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> which may be a critical determinant for the death - promoting activity of these proteins .
